{{Redirect|Sombrero Island}} {{Designation list | designation1 = Ramsar | designation1_offname = Sombrero Island Nature Reserve Marine Park | designation1_date = 22 May 2018 | designation1_number = 2354<ref name="RSIS">{{Cite web|title=Sombrero Island Nature Reserve Marine Park|website=[[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Sites Information Service|url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/2354|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref>}} [[File:Anguilla-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|right|Map of Anguilla; Sombrero is at upper left]]
'''Sombrero''', also known as '''Hat Island''', is part of the [[British overseas territory]] of [[Anguilla]] and is the northernmost island of the [[Lesser Antilles]]. It lies {{convert|54|km|mi|abbr=on}} north-west of Anguilla across the Dog and Prickly Pear Passage. The distance to [[Dog Island, Anguilla|Dog Island]], the next nearest island of Anguilla, is {{convert|38|km|mi|abbr=off}}.
Sombrero is {{convert|1.67|km|yd|2|abbr=off}} long north-south, and {{convert|0.38|km|yd|2|abbr=on}} wide. The land area is {{convert|0.38|km2|acre|2|abbr=on}}. Originally, when viewed from the sea, the island had the shape of a [[Sombrero|sombrero hat]] but [[guano]] mining operations have left the island with precipitous sides and a relatively flat top that is {{convert|12|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[above sea level]]. The surface of the island is rough, and vegetation is sparse.
The guano-mining operation yielded some 3000 [[ton]]s of phosphate a year by 1870. By 1890, the phosphate reserves had been exhausted.
==Lighthouse== {{Infobox lighthouse | name = Sombrero Lighthouse | image_name = | image_width = | caption = | location = | pushpin_map = Anguilla#Caribbean | relief = 1 | pushpin_map_caption = Anguilla | pushpin = lighthouse | coordinates = {{coord|18|35|11.7|N|63|25|35.4|W|display=inline}} | coordinates_footnotes = | yearbuilt = 1868 (first) | yearlit = 2001 (current) | automated = | yeardeactivated = | foundation = concrete base | construction = concrete tower | shape = three-stage cylindrical tower with beacon | marking = white tower | height = {{convert|15|m|ft}} | focalheight = {{convert|28|m|ft}} | lens = | currentlens = | lightsource = solar power | intensity = | range = {{convert|17|nmi}} | characteristic = Fl W 10s. | fogsignal = | racon = | admiralty = J5650 | canada = | NGA = 14712 | ARLHS = ANG-001 | USCG = | country = | countrynumber = | countrylink = | managingagent = Government of Anguilla<ref name=rowlett>{{cite rowlett|aia|accessdate=27 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite ngall|110|2016}}</ref> | heritage = | module = }}
The [[lighthouse]] marks the [[Anegada Passage]], which is the route from Europe into the Caribbean. The first lighthouse was erected in 1868. In 1960, [[Hurricane Donna]] damaged this lighthouse, with the result that a new lighthouse replaced it in 1962. The lighthouses were manned from 1868 to 2001. In that year, [[Trinity House]] donated and installed the current, automated tower, which is a {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} round tower, painted white. Anguilla's Department of Fisheries and Marine Resources is responsible for the maintenance of the navigational aids.
==History== [[File:Sombrero map.jpg|thumb|left|Plan of Sombrero in about 1880 showing mining operations]] As a result of the [[Treaty of Utrecht]] in 1714, Sombrero passed into the hands of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]]. Captain [[Viscount Lake|Warwick Lake]] of [[HMS Recruit (1806)|''Recruit'']] [[marooning|marooned]] an impressed seaman, Robert Jeffrey, there on 13 December 1807. As it turned out, Jeffrey survived. A passing American vessel, the schooner ''Adams'' from [[Marblehead, Massachusetts]], had rescued him. Still, a [[court martial]] dismissed Lake from the Royal Navy.
In 1814, and again in 1825, a British [[Geology|geologist]] surveyed the island and found that it abounded in [[guano]] and reported this to the British government.
In 1856 the Americans claimed the island, and in a very short period of time quarried 100,000 tons of [[phosphate]] that served as fertilizer for the exhausted lands of the [[Southern United States|Southern States]]. Uniquely, an important insurrection occurred when West Indian black workers revolted against the “slavery proclivities” of a white American superintendent vis-à-vis wage-earning free men. Four of the 200 workers "fatally injured" Superintendent Snow and commandeered the island and company money and stores.<ref>''New York Times'', 13 August 1860: “Negro Insurrection on a Guano Island”.</ref>
The British later intervened and demanded compensation from the United States for the occupation. The conflicting claims to the island were settled in Britain's favour in 1867.
Sombrero, lying in the route of shipping from England to [[South-America|South]] and [[Central America]], lay in an area with many hazards and in 1848 the [[Admiralty]] was asked to install a light on it. On 30 June 1859, the [[Royal Mail Steam Packet Company]]'s ship ''Paramatta'' was wrecked on her maiden voyage on [[Anegada Island#Horseshoe Reef|Horseshoe Reef]],<ref>''The Illustrated London News'', Vol. 47, no. 1323, p. 17-18.</ref> which resulted in another request to the Admiralty. The [[lighthouse]] was then built and first exhibited its light on the evening of 1 January 1868.
Ironically, ''Paramatta'' and the Lighthouse built following her demise were both constructed by the same shipyard, the [[Thames Ironworks and Shipbuilding Company]], on the banks of the River Lea in Blackwall, London. ''Paramatta'' was the last ship launched from their Middlesex bank, while the lighthouse was built on the Essex side, the yard occupying premises on either side of the river.<ref>Thames Iron Works Historical Catalogue: Souvenir prepared for the Festival of Empire, Crystal Palace 1911, p.42 and p.111</ref> In 1871, the lease of the island was sold for £55,000 and then sold again for £110,000 to the New Sombrero Phosphate Company, which led to litigation in ''[[Erlanger v. New Sombrero Phosphate Co]]'' (1878) 3 App Cas 1218.<ref>{{Cite book |author1=Len Sealy |author2=Sarah Worthington |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Cases and Materials in Company Law | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2008 | location = Oxford | pages = 81}}</ref>
[[File:Sombrero light1.jpg|thumb|left|The superintendent of Sombrero's house in about 1880]]
From the early 1870s until 1885, a [[Cornwall|Cornish]] mining engineer, Thomas Corfield, was [[Management|Superintendent]] of Sombrero. His duties included organizing the conveying of the guano to a spot which was convenient for loading the [[lighter (barge)|lighters]] to take the guano to the ships lying off the island, overseeing the construction of [[derrick]]s and engine houses, and arranging for the laying of the [[tram]] lines for the wagons, which were loaded at the quarries. The guano was just piled in dumps near the engine houses and derricks. There was no semblance of a [[port]] and no beach.
The black workers were recruited from various islands and lived in wooden huts during their term of service. Stores and various supplies were obtained from a merchant at [[Philipsburg, Sint Maarten|Philipsburg]], [[Sint Maarten]], a Mr Nesbit. The company's [[schooner]] ''Logos'' brought supplies and also took the black labourers to and from their homes on the other islands.
The superintendent's house was a wooden [[bungalow]] near the middle of the island, and around it were grouped the quarters of the technicians, store keepers, and lighthouse keepers, and other wooden buildings. On the side opposite to the main buildings was a small building for the superintendent. There was a wide [[veranda]] round the house and he used to live there with his family, except near the [[Atlantic hurricane season|hurricane season]].<ref>Notes by Thomas Joseph Corfield - Made July 1957.</ref>
In 1890, the phosphate works on the island were abandoned and by 1893 the lighthouse had come under the authority of the [[Board of trade|British Board of Trade]], later the [[Department for Transport|Department of Transport]]. Administration of the light was carried out by [[Trinity House]]. In 1931, the old light system was changed and improved to 200,000 candle power and the tower received its first major repair when the basement was encased in concrete.
On 20 July 1962, after the destruction caused by [[Hurricane Donna]] in 1960, the present lighthouse was put into operation and the old tower demolished on 28 July 1962.<ref>A Visit to Sombrero by P. Bannis, Government Information Service Bulletin Vol I, No 2, July 1978, which quoted from the writings of Mr. William Hodge in the Sombrero Visitors' Book</ref> The lighthouse is located near the centre of the island, and reaches a height of almost {{convert|166|ft|m}} above sea level. It protects ships passing from the Atlantic Ocean to the Caribbean Sea through the [[Anegada Passage]]. Full responsibility for the light passed from Trinity House to the Anguillan government on 1 December 2001.<ref name="Lords 2005">Written Answers - House of Lords:Anguilla:Sombero Island Lighthouse (21 February 2005)</ref> <!--<gallery>--><!-- Unsourced image removed: File:Sombrero2.jpg--><!--</gallery>-->
==Population== Until recently the only inhabitants were the staff of the [[lighthouse]] but the light was automated in 2002 and now the island is uninhabited. The only visitors are the occasional fishermen, biologists engaged in fieldwork, and the occasional scuba group visiting the island for its interesting dive sites and post-apocalyptic surface. <!--<gallery>--><!-- Unsourced image removed: File:Sombrero3.jpg--><!--</gallery>-->
==Wildlife== The island is noted for the endemic [[Sombrero ameiva]], a widespread and easily seen lizard species on the island. A recently discovered dwarf gecko, ''[[Sphaerodactylus]]'', may be endemic and has been tentatively named the Sombrero dwarf gecko. The [[Anguilla Bank anole]] also inhabits the island. This island also has a unique [[Lasioglossum]] bee.<ref name="Engel 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Engel|first1=Engel|title=A New Species of Dialictus from Sombrero Island, Anguilla (Hymenoptera, Halictidae)|journal=Zookeys|date=2011|volume=86|page=61|doi=10.3897/zookeys.86.909|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.3897/zookeys.86.909|accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref>
The surrounding waters are feeding areas for [[hawksbill turtle]]s. During the late [[Pleistocene]], the island was inhabited by a now-extinct giant tortoise, ''[[Chelonoidis]] sombrerensis''.<ref name="Hansen">{{Cite journal | last = Hansen | first = D. M. | author2 = Donlan, C. J. | author3 = Griffiths, C. J. | author4 = Campbell, K. J. | title = Ecological history and latent conservation potential: large and giant tortoises as a model for taxon substitutions | journal = [[Ecography (journal)|Ecography]] | volume = 33 | issue = 2 | pages = 272–284 | publisher = [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] | location = | date = April 2010 | url = http://www.advancedconservation.org/library/hansen_etal_2010.pdf | issn = | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0587.2010.06305.x | id = | accessdate = 2011-02-26 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110724224354/http://www.advancedconservation.org/library/hansen_etal_2010.pdf | archivedate = 2011-07-24 | df = }}</ref>
Sombrero has been identified as an [[Important Bird Area]] by [[BirdLife International]] because of its breeding [[seabird]]s.<ref name=bli>{{cite web |url= http://www.birdlife.org |title= Sombrero|accessdate=2012-11-23 |work= BirdLife data zone: Important Bird Areas |publisher= BirdLife International |year= 2012}}</ref> The island has also been designated as a protected [[Ramsar site]] since 2018.<ref name="RSIS"/> It supports internationally important numbers of: * [[Masked booby|Masked boobies]] (''Sula dactylatra''): 27 pairs (54 + birds, 4% of Caribbean population) 2002 * [[Brown booby|Brown boobies]] (''Sula leucogaster''): 386 pairs (772 + birds, 5% of Caribbean population) 1999 * [[Bridled tern]]s (''Sterna anaethetus''): 270 pairs (540 birds, 4% of Caribbean population) 1998 * [[Brown noddy|Brown noddies]] (''Anous stolidus''): 700 pairs (1400 birds, 5% of Caribbean population) 1998 * [[Sooty tern]]s (''Onychoprion fuscata'') <ref>UK Overseas Territories Conservation Forum. Ramsar Information Sheet: UK45006</ref>
==See also== * [[List of lighthouses in Anguilla]]
==Citations and references== '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}} '''References''' * Lazell, J. (1964) "The reptiles of Sombrero, West Indies". ''Copeia'': 716-718.
==External links== *https://web.archive.org/web/20071006203854/http://sombrero.ai/island.htm
{{coord|18|35|21|N|63|25|31|W|display=title|region:AI_type:isle_source:dewiki}}

revision.text:
{{Crisis in Bolivarian Venezuela}}
The '''[[Venezuelan protests (2014–present)|2016 Venezuelan protests]]''' began in early January following controversy surrounding the [[Venezuelan parliamentary election, 2015|2015 Venezuelan parliamentary elections]] and the increasing hardships felt by Venezuelans.<ref name="1000protests">{{cite news|last1=Cawthorne|first1=Andrew|title=Small protests proliferate in simmering Venezuela|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-venezuela-politics-protests-idUKKCN0WJ1CG|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=17 March 2016}}</ref> [[Timeline of the 2014 Venezuelan protests|The series of protests originally began in February 2014]] when hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans protested due to high levels of criminal violence, inflation, and chronic scarcity of basic goods because of policies created the [[Venezuelan government]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Lopez|first=Linette|title=Why The United States Has Done Nothing About Venezuela|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/why-the-us-wont-touch-venezuela-2014-4|accessdate=12 April 2014|newspaper=Business Insider|date=11 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Protesters in Venezuela Press Government|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304834704579401612202743396|accessdate=12 April 2014|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=23 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuelans protest en masse in rival rallies|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2014/02/24/venezuelans-protest-en-masse-in-rival-rallies/|accessdate=12 April 2014|newspaper=Borneo Post|date=24 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title= Venezuela's Maduro says 2013 annual inflation was 56.2 pct|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/30/venezuela-inflation-annual-idUSL2N0K90V020131230 |accessdate= 19 January 2014|newspaper= Reuters|date= 30 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Venezuela Inflation Hits 16-Year High as Shortages Rise|url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-11-07/venezuela-inflation-hits-16-year-high-as-shortages-rise.html |accessdate=16 February 2014|newspaper= Bloomberg|date= 7 November 2013}}</ref> though the size of protests had decreased since 2014.
In the first two months of 2016, over 1,000 protests and dozens of [[looting]] incidents were recorded throughout Venezuela.<ref name="1000protests"/> Much of the looting occurred due to [[shortages in Venezuela]] with Venezuelans forced to stand in the sun for hours while waiting in line for scarce products.<ref name="1000protests"/> By September, Venezuela saw some of its largest protests in the country's history with over one million demonstrating on 1 September 2016 and 26 October 2016. Into November, protests ceased due to the Vatican-backed dialogue between the opposition and the Bolivarian government, though the talks began to fall apart by the end of December. The protests are listed below according to the month they had happened.
==January== [[File:Chavista protest January 2016.jpg|250px|thumb|Chavistas protesting the removal of Chávez and Bolivar images from the National Assembly on 7 January 2016.]] * '''5 January''' – After their success in the [[Venezuelan parliamentary election, 2015|2015 Venezuelan parliamentary election]], opposition lawmakers were sworn into office obtaining a majority status while Bolivarian lawmakers walked out in protest shouting demeaning statements at the opposition as they left. With journalists granted to enter the National Assembly building for the first time in years, chanting and scuffles were reported and captured on camera. Outside of the building, hundreds of opposition supporters gathered while a larger crowd of government supporters gathered outside of [[Miraflores Palace]] denouncing the newly elected opposition parliament.<ref name=CBCjan5>{{cite news|title=Venezuela's new legislature opens with rancorous session|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/venezuela-legislature-open-1.3391163|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=5 January 2016}}</ref> * '''7 January''' – After the opposition-led National Assembly removed images of [[Hugo Chávez]] and [[Simón Bolívar]], two symbols of the [[Bolivarian Revolution]], from the National Assembly building, the Bolivarian government called for protests and to place the image of Chávez "on every street corner", with President Maduro ordering all members of the military to place images of both Hugo Chávez and Simón Bolivar in their homes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sanchez|first1=Fabiola|title=Venezuelan socialists protest new congress' ban on Chavez|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/venezuelan-socialists-protest-congress-ban-chavez-050049477.html|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=8 January 2016}}</ref> * '''13 January''' – Early in the day, three opposition lawmakers led protests outside of the [[Supreme Tribunal of Justice (Venezuela)|Supreme Tribunal of Justice]] building after the [[Lame duck (politics)|lame duck]] parliament stacked the court with pro-government judges in December which blocked an opposition supermajority in the parliament.<ref name=CBCjan5/><ref name="REUTjan13">{{cite news|last1=Cawthorne|first1=Andrew|title=Venezuela opposition seeks to unblock congressional deadlock|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKCN0UR1UF20160113|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=13 January 2016}}</ref> While lawmakers were entering the National Assembly building, government supporters threw tomatoes and fireworks at them.<ref name="REUTjan13"/> With no choice but to agree with the government-stacked Supreme Tribunal of Justice that threatened to make laws passed by the National Assembly invalid unless three opposition lawmakers under investigation were not sworn in, the opposition-led National Assembly accepted the terms and allowed the three lawmakers to leave the parliament.<ref name="REUTjan13"/>
==March== * '''3 March''' - Violence erupts in [[San Cristóbal, Táchira|San Cristóbal]] between students and riot police after a by the supreme court ruling blocked the power of the opposition-controlled [[National Assembly of Venezuela|National Assembly]] to review government appointments of the court's justices.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35716100 |title=Venezuela students protest against Supreme Court ruling}}</ref> * '''13 March''' – The opposition launches renewed protests calling for President Maduro's removal from office. Thousands of Venezuelans protest either supporting or denouncing Maduro's government.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gupta|first1=Girish|last2=Cawthorne|first2=Andrew|title=Venezuela opposition launches protests, Maduro counters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKCN0WE0UX|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=13 March 2016}}</ref> * '''27 March''' - A poll shows that two thirds of Venezuelans want Maduro's presidency to end this year and referendum results would be expected to show 52% wanting him removed from office.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/two-thirds-of-venezuelans-say-maduro-presidency-should-end-this-year-poll-idUSKCN0WS0JO |title=Two-thirds of Venezuelans say Maduro presidency should end this year: poll}}</ref> * '''29 March''' – During a protest surrounding increased bus fares in San Cristobal, two policeman were killed while another four were injured when a bus driven by protesters struck the officers.<ref name="REUTmarch29">{{cite news|last1=Polanco|first1=Angry|last2=Ramirez|first2=Carlos|title=Two Venezuelan police officers killed in protest|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-protests-idUSKCN0WV2K3|accessdate=3 April 2016|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=29 March 2016}}</ref> * '''30 March''' - The opposition-controlled National Assembly passes an amnesty bill to free over 70 opposition leaders incarcerated during the protests.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35924647 |title=Venezuela's National Assembly passes amnesty bill}}</ref> President Maduro vows to veto this bill but the opposition can overturn it due to their control over the National Assembly. However, Maduro can pass this to the Supreme Tribunal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/03/30/Venezuelas-Maduro-vows-to-veto-amnesty-bill-passed-by-National-Assembly/2471459353316/?spt=hts&or=5 |title=Venezuela's Maduro vows to veto amnesty bill passed by National Assembly}}</ref> The opposition also plans a referendum to have Maduro removed from office.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/03/29/Venezuelan-opposition-preparing-referendum-to-oust-Maduro/7201459269012/?st |title=Venezuelan opposition preparing referendum to oust Maduro}}</ref> * '''31 March''' - The National Assembly passes a legislation to make it easier for pensioners and retirees to pay for food and medicine in response to the rapid inflation.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/03/31/Venezuelan-retirees-could-see-grocery-bill-help-in-wake-of-180-inflation/5651459438964/?spt=hs&or=tn_int |title=Venezuelan retirees could see grocery bill help in wake of 180% inflation}}</ref>
==April== * '''25 April''' - The supreme court rules that the opposition's proposed amendment to shorten the presidential term limit from 6 to 4 years cannot be applied retroactively, ending any attempt to shorten Maduro's rule.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36136282 |title=Top Venezuela court blocks bid to cut President Maduro's term}}</ref> * '''26 April''' – Opposition obtains documents to proceed with a referendum against President Maduro.<ref name="FNLpetitionAPR">{{cite news|title=Angry Venezuelans take to streets, setting up barricades and raiding shops for food|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/04/28/angry-venezuelans-take-to-streets-setting-barricades-and-raiding-shops-for-food/|accessdate=28 April 2016|agency=[[Fox News Latino]]|date=28 April 2016}}</ref> * '''27 April''' – With 2 of 3 Venezuelans wanting President Maduro removed from office, Venezuelans begin signing documents to recall Maduro as the opposition holds a rally for signatures. Blackouts and other issues surrounding the Bolivarian government results in looting with over 100 arrested in Maracaibo.<ref name="FNLpetitionAPR"/> * '''29 April''' – During a protest against shortages of electricity in Caracas, opposition leader [[Jesús Torrealba]] was attack by government supporters.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Winter|first1=Chase|title=Supply shortages force Venezuela's largest brewer to halt production|url=http://www.dw.com/en/supply-shortages-force-venezuelas-largest-brewer-to-halt-production/a-19226196|accessdate=30 April 2016|agency=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=30 April 2016}}</ref>
==May== * '''2 May''' – Just days after being granted documents to begin an effort to recall President Maduro, Venezuela's unified opposition delivered petitions with what it said were 1.8 million signatures, over 9 times the 200,000 necessary signatures needed to begin the next phase of the recall procedure.<ref>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Recall effort builds against Venezuelan president|url=http://www.dw.com/en/recall-effort-builds-against-venezuelan-president/a-19230763|accessdate=3 May 2016|agency=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=2 May 2016}}</ref> * '''11 May''' – Over 5,000 desperate Venezuelans looted a [[Maracay]] market for food. The incident resulted in two deaths, several injuries and millions of dollars in damage.<ref name="PAPmay2016">{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Sabrina|title=Venezuela: Countless Wounded after 5,000 Loot Supermarket|url=https://panampost.com/sabrina-martin/2016/05/11/venezuela-looting-wounded-5000-supermarket/|accessdate=12 May 2016|agency=[[PanAm Post]]|date=11 May 2016}}</ref> * '''18 May''' – Thousands of Venezuelans protest outside of the CNE electoral body in Caracas demanding a recall of President Maduro.<ref>{{cite news|title=Anti-Government Protesters Clash With Police in Venezuela|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/05/18/world/americas/ap-lt-venezuela-protest-.html?_r=0|accessdate=26 May 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 May 2016}}</ref>
==June== * '''9 June''' – During a protest which opposition lawmakers attended denouncing what they called the poor performance of Venezuela's electoral body, members of the National Guard stationed outside of the electoral offices pushed protesters toward a pro-government group of [[Colectivo (Venezuela)|colectivos]] who attacked protesters, with one lawmaker, [[Julio Borges]], being hit by a pipe in the face.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela opposition leader hit with a pipe|url=http://www.lfpress.com/2016/06/09/venezuela-opposition-leader-hit-with-a-pipe-in-the-face|accessdate=10 June 2016|agency=''[[The London Free Press]]''|date=9 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Julio Borges: Colectivos nos agredieron con tubos y explosivos|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/09/julio-borges-colectivos-nos-agredieron-con-tubos-y-explosivos/|accessdate=10 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Recrudece violencia contra diputados de la MUD y se convierte en su "penitencia diaria"|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/09/violencia-contra-parlamentarios-de-la-mud-ha-recrudecido-convirtiendose-en-una-penitencia-diaria/|accessdate=10 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]|date=9 June 2016}}</ref> In Petare, Miranda, looting and protests occurred with multiple people shot by Venezuelan authorities, with 21 year-old Jose Antonio Tovar being killed in the gunfire.<ref name=TRES>{{cite news|title=Tres venezolanos murieron baleados en una semana durante protestas por comida|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/13/tres-venezolanos-murieron-baleados-en-una-semana-durante-protestas-por-comida/|accessdate=15 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]|date=13 June 2016}}</ref> * '''12 June''' – In Cerezal, Sucre, protests occurred with about 10 people were injured from buckshot and gunfire fired by the National Guard, while 21 year-old Luis Fuentes Josmel being killed.<ref name=TRES/> * '''14 June''' – In [[Cumaná]], one of the largest instances of protests and looting due to the lack of food occurred with dozens of shops looted and at least three people killed, with reports of government authorities participating in the looting as well.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arde Cumaná por falta de alimentos: Protestas y saqueos sacuden la ciudad (Videos + Fotos)|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/14/arde-cumana-por-falta-de-alimentos-protestas-y-saqueos-sacuden-la-ciudad-videos-fotos/|accessdate=15 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]|date=14 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Extraoficial: Tres fallecidos habrían dejado saqueos en Cumaná|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/14/extraoficial-tres-fallecidos-habrian-dejado-saqueos-en-cumana/|accessdate=14 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]|date=14 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=En Cumaná también saqueó la policía (VIDEO)|url=http://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/06/14/en-cumana-tambien-saqueo-la-policia-video/|accessdate=15 June 2016|agency=[[La Patilla]]|date=14 June 2016}}</ref> * '''20 June''' - Citizens across the country begin queuing up for fingerprint vandalism of 1,850,000 signatures on a referendum to recall President Maduro.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics/venezuela-opposition-lines-up-to-seek-maduro-recall-idUSKCN0Z61ZX |title=Venezuela opposition lines up to seek Maduro recall}}</ref>
==August==
* '''22 August''' – [[Capriles Radonski]] announces a march called the "''Toma de Caracas''" (Taking of Caracas) to be held on 1 September, with a goal to mobilize opposition supporters nationwide and to place pressure on the CNE to give answers about the referendum.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leopoldo López respalda la movilización "Toma de Caracas" que se realizará el 1° de septiembre|url=http://noticiero.venevision.net/politica/2016/agosto/7/165174=leopoldo-lopez-respalda-la-movilizacion-toma-de-caracas-que-se-realizara-el-1-de-septiembre|website=Noticiero Venevision|accessdate=22 August 2016}}</ref>
==September== [[File:Toma de Maracaibo.jpg|250px|thumb|right|Protest in Maracaibo demanding a recall of President Maduro, 16 September 2016.]] {{expand section|date=February 2017}} * '''1 September''' – Opposition protesters marched to Caracas on a national level in the Taking of Caracas to push for the recall referendum of Maduro.<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Taking of Caracas’ protests push recall of Venezuela president Maduro|url=http://www.cctv-america.com/2016/09/01/taking-of-caracas-protests-push-recall-of-venezuela-president-maduro|publisher=CCTV America|access-date = September 1, 2016}}</ref> [[Chúo Torrealba]] called for a [[cacerolazo]] the same night.<ref>{{cite web|title="Chúo" Torrealba anunció "gran cacerolazo" hoy a las 8:00 pm|url=http://www.el-nacional.com/politica/Chuo-Torrealba-Gran-cacerolazo-hoy_0_913708770.html|website=El Nacional|access-date = 1 September 2016}}</ref> * '''2 September''' – People from Villa Rosa, [[Nueva Esparta]] state, received [[Maduro]] with a cacerolazo while he was inaugurating houses of the Gran Misión Barrio Nuevo, Barrio Tricolor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Difunden video del cacerolazo al presidente Maduro en Villa Rosa, Margarita (+Fotos)|url=http://www.2001.com.ve/en-la-agenda/139379/difunden-video-del-cacerolazo-a-maduro-en-villa-rosa--margarita---fotos-.html|website=2001|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> * '''3 September''' – At least 30 persons were detained by the [[SEBIN]] after the cacerolazo in Villa Rosa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sebin detuvo a más de 30 personas en Villa Rosa por cacerolazos a Maduro|url=http://www.el-nacional.com/politica/Sebin-Villa-Rosa-cacerolazos-Margarita_0_914908540.html|website=El Nacional|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref>
==October== [[File:Venezuela protest 26 October.jpg|250px|thumb|26 October 2016 protest that gathered an estimated 1.2 million Venezuelans.]] * '''21 October''' –The CNE suspends the referendum only days before preliminary elections were to be held.<ref name="FOXsuspend">{{cite news|title=Venezuela Suspends Recall Campaign Against President Maduro|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/10/20/venezuela-suspends-recall-campaign-against-president-maduro.html|accessdate=21 October 2016|work=[[Fox News]]|date=20 October 2016}}</ref> The CNE blamed alleged voter fraud as the reason for the cancellation of the referendum.<ref name="FOXsuspend"/> Opposition leaders responded by calling for protests on 26 October against the CNE's actions.<ref name="FOXsuspend"/> * '''22 October''' –Several thousands Venezuelans march through Caracas protesting against the suspension of the recall referendum. Demonstrators were led by [[Lilian Tintori]] and Patricia Gutierrez, wives of arrested opposition politicians.<ref name="REUToct2016">{{cite news|last1=Buitrago|first1=Daisy|last2=Oré|first2=Diego|title=Maduro opponents march after Venezuela referendum sunk|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKCN12M0SY|accessdate=23 October 2016|work=[[Reuters]]|date=22 October 2016}}</ref> * '''23 October''' –The opposition-led National Assembly gathers declaring that "there had been a breakdown of constitutional order and a continued state of coup led from the highest level of government by President Nicolas Maduro". Government supporters storm the National Assembly, stealing phones and assaulting opposition lawmakers while also vandalizing the building.<ref name="CNNoct25">{{cite news|last1=Brocchetto|first1=Marilia|title=Venezuela: Protesters promise turning point|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/25/americas/venezuela-protests/|accessdate=26 October 2016|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 October 2016}}</ref> * '''24 October''' –Students nationwide stage protests, with hundreds of students from San Cristobal, Caracas and Valencia taking to the streets to demonstrate with clashes reported in San Cristobal where National Guardsmen fired rubber bullets at students.<ref>{{cite news|title=Estudiantes protestaron en varias ciudades para exigir Referendo y así los reprimieron (Fotos)|url=https://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/10/24/estudiantes-protestaron-en-varias-ciudades-para-exigir-referendo-y-asi-los-reprimieron-fotos/|accessdate=26 October 2016|work=[[La Patilla]]|date=24 October 2016}}</ref> Henrique Capriles Radonski announces the starting areas and routes of the "Toma de Venezuela" ("Taking of Venezuela") protests destined for 26 October.<ref>{{cite news|title=Estos son los puntos de concentración para la Toma de Venezuela de este #26OCT|url=https://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/10/24/estos-son-los-puntos-de-concentracion-para-la-toma-de-venezuela-de-este-26oct/|accessdate=26 October 2016|work=[[La Patilla]]|date=24 October 2016}}</ref> * '''25 October''' –The National Assembly votes for President Maduro to face questioning on 1 November for possible impeachment proceedings through the government-supporting Supreme Court.<ref name="CNNoct25"/> * '''26 October''' –Foreign journalists are prevented from entering Venezuela before the day's protests.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela impide entrar a varios periodistas antes de la marcha contra la suspensión del revocatorio|url=http://www.univision.com/noticias/crisis-en-venezuela/venezuela-impide-entrar-a-varios-periodistas-antes-de-la-marcha-contra-la-suspension-del-revocatorio|accessdate=26 October 2016|work=[[Univision]]|date=26 October 2016}}</ref> It is estimated that 1.2 million Venezuelans protested, demanding President Maduro to leave office, with Caracas protests remaining calm while protests in other states resulted in clashes between demonstrators and authorities, leaving 1 policeman dead, 120 injured and 147 arrested.<ref name="AMBITO">{{cite news|title=Con multitudinarias marchas, oposición venezolana presionó a Maduro para que reactive referendo|url=http://www.ambito.com/860181-con-multitudinarias-marchas-oposicion-venezolana-presiono-a-maduro-para-que-reactive-referendo|accessdate=27 October 2016|work=[[Ámbito Financiero]]|date=26 October 2016}}</ref> Opposition leaders also called for a 12-hour national strike for 28 October while Henrique Capriles stated, "Today we are giving a deadline to the government. I tell the coward who is in [[Miraflores Palace|Miraflores]] ... that on 3 November the Venezuelan people are coming to Caracas because we are going to Miraflores".<ref name="AMBITO"/> * '''28 October''' –The national strike has only partial participation after the Bolivarian government threatens business owners that their companies will be taken over and they will be arrested if any strikes occurred, with reports of military and [[SEBIN]] personnel outside of businesses reported.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ellsworth|first1=Brian|last2=Polanco|first2=Angry|title=Venezuelan opposition strike patchy amid government threats|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKCN12S1QD|accessdate=30 October 2016|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 October 2016}}</ref>
==November== * '''1 November''' –National Assembly President and opposition leader Henry Ramos Allup announced the cancellation of the 3 November march to the Miraflores presidential palace, though some opposition leaders gave the government a deadline of 12 November until new elections should be formed or else they would announce marches to the palace.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rosati|first1=Andrew|title=Venezuela Opposition Cancels Protest, Delays Political Trial|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-11-01/venezuela-opposition-calls-off-protest-delays-political-trial|accessdate=2 November 2016|work=Bloomberg|date=1 November 2016}}</ref> President Maduro respected the decision to cancel the march toward his palace, calling anyone who organizes marches toward Miraflores a "criminal" and stated that the political party Popular Will was a "outlawed terrorist group", calling for courts to "take action" against them.<ref>{{cite news|title=Maduro: Quien llame a marchar a Miraflores es un criminal|url=https://www.lapatilla.com/site/2016/11/01/maduro-quien-llame-a-marchar-a-miraflores-es-un-criminal/|accessdate=2 November 2016|work=[[La Patilla]]|date=1 November 2016}}</ref>
==December== [[File:Mesa de diálogo entre el gobierno de Venezuela y la MUD, panorámica.jpg|thumb| Vatican-backed dialogue with the Bolivarian government]] * '''7 December''' – The opposition announces a halt on Vatican-backed dialogue with the Bolivarian government since they would not release political prisoners and hold recall elections. Bolivarian government officials also stated that the talks had halted with the opposition.<ref>{{cite news|first1=Deutsche Welle|title=Venezuela's opposition walks away from Vatican-backed talks|url=http://www.dw.com/en/venezuelas-opposition-walks-away-from-vatican-backed-talks/a-36672319|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=7 December 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Timeline of the 2014 Venezuelan protests]] *[[Timeline of the 2015 Venezuelan protests]] *[[Timeline of the 2017 Venezuelan protests]]
==References== {{reflist|3}}

revision.text:
{{coord|42.78|N|89.34|E|display=title}} {{Chinese |title=Turpan Depression |pic=Turpan Depression, nestled at the foot of China’s Bogda Mountains.jpg |picsize=250px |piccap=The Turpan Depression, nestled at the foot of China's [[Bogda Shan|Bogda Shan Mountains]]. |t=吐魯番盆地 |s=吐鲁番盆地 |p=Tǔlǔfán Péndì |uig=تۇرپان ئويمانلىقى|usy=Турпан Ойманлиқи|uly=''Turpan Oymanliqi'' }}
The '''Turpan Depression''', or '''Turfan Depression''', is a [[fault (geology)|fault]]-bounded trough located around and south of the city-[[oasis]] of [[Turpan]], in the [[Xinjiang]] Autonomous Region in far [[western China]], about {{convert|150|km}} southeast of the regional capital [[Ürümqi]]. It includes [[Lake Ayding]], {{convert|−154|m|0}}, the [[List of places on land with elevations below sea level|second or third lowest]] [[Depression (geology)|depression]] on [[Earth]].<ref> After the [[Jordan valley]] (−430 m), and equal to the [[Afar Depression]] within the accuracy of reported measurements (−155 m to −153 m). {{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/imagegallery/image_feature_533.html |title=NASA - Bogda Mountains |publisher=www.nasa.gov |accessdate=2009-10-09 }}</ref> By some measures, it is also the hottest and driest area in China during the summer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2010/201004/20100405/article_433203.htm|publisher=Shanghai Daily|title=If you can stand the heat, then the Turpan Basin is the place to be|date=4-5-2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407094332/http://www.shanghaidaily.com/sp/article/2010/201004/20100405/article_433203.htm|archivedate=April 7, 2010|df=}} </ref>
==Geology and relief== The Turpan Basin is a fault-bounded trough located in the eastern part of the [[Tian Shan]]. It covers an area of {{convert|50000|km2}}. The surrounding mountain ranges are: the central Tian Shan in the west, the [[Bogda Shan]] in the north-west, the [[Haerlike Shan]] in the north-west, and the [[Jueluotage Shan]] in the south. Beyond the surrounding mountain ranges lie the [[Dzungaria|Junggar Basin]] in the north and the [[Tarim Basin]] in the south.
Some geographers also use the term [[Turpan-Hami Basin]], which is understood as including the Turpan Depression along with the Hami Depression (located to the east of the Turpan Depression, and to the southwest of the city of [[Hami City|Hami]]) and the Liaodong Uplift separating the two depressions. A source using this terminology gave the area of the Turpan Depression proper as {{convert|28600|km2|abbr=on}}, that of the Hami Depression as {{convert|19300|km2|abbr=on}}, and for the entire Turpan-Hami Basin, as {{convert|48000|km2|abbr=on}}.<ref name=uranium>{{citation |first=Franz J.|last=Dahlkamp |isbn=978-3-540-78557-6 |title=Uranium Deposits of the World: Asia |publisher= Springer |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ShzwRGs5mDYC&pg=PA40 |pages=40–41 |date=2009-09-16 }}</ref>
[[Image:Turpan-flaming-mountains-camellos-d01.jpg|thumb|250px|Basin scene near [[Flaming Mountains]]]]
The Turpan Basin formed in a [[shear zone]] during the [[Permian|Late Permian]] due to motion between the East European and the Angaran [[craton]]. It was subsequently deformed by the collision of the Indian and Eurasian plates in the [[Cenozoic]]. In the latter deformation, a thrust fault belt running from east to west, the [[Flaming Mountains]], was formed in the center of the basin. The Flaming Mountains are {{convert|98|km|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|9|km|abbr=on}} wide; the highest peak reaches an elevation of {{convert|831.7|m|abbr=on}} above sea level. The [[Turfan volcano]] is located near Turpan.
Also in the center of the basin lies the [[Ayding Lake]] (Moonlight Lake) which has an elevation of {{convert|154.5|m|abbr=on}} below sea level, the [[List of elevation extremes by country|sixth lowest exposed elevation on the Earth's land surface]]. It is the lowest surface point in China.
The Shihongtan [[uranium]] ore deposit is located at the southwestern margin of the Turpan Depression, some {{convert|35|km|abbr=on}} south-southwest from Turpan City.<ref name=uranium/>
==History== [[Image:Turpan-gaochang-d12.jpg|thumb|250px|Ruins of Gaochang]] The ancient city of [[Gaochang]] was a key point on the ancient [[Silk Road]] and dates back to the 1st century BC. It was burnt down in wars in the 14th century. The [[Bezeklik Thousand Buddha Caves]], which are located in the [[Flaming Mountains]]' [[Mutou Valley]], about {{convert|30|km|abbr=on}} east of the city of Turpan, have been hewn into the rock from the [[Tang dynasty]] era up to the time of the [[Yuan dynasty]] (13th century). The caves are famous for their murals, which can still be found in about 40 of the 77 known caves. The desert climate has favored preservation of the content of the [[Astana Cemetery|Astana-Karakhoja ancient tombs]], which are located about 6 km from the ancient city of Gaochang. The tombs are the burial place for nobles, officials, and others who were interred there from the times of the [[Jin dynasty (265–420)|Western Jin dynasty]] until the middle of the Tang dynasty era.
==Climate== The Turpan Basin has a harsh, continental [[desert climate]] in which the precipitation is far less than the potential evaporation. At Turpan City, July is the hottest month with a 24-hour average temperature of {{convert|32.2|C|1}} and January the coldest with a 24-hour average temperature of {{convert|−7.6|C|1}}. Monthly rainfall is highest in June, at {{convert|2.9|mm}} and lowest in February and April, at {{convert|0.5|mm|abbr=on}}. The annual average precipitation is only {{convert|15.7|mm|abbr=on}}, falling on only 13 days per year. In contrast to this, the potential annual evaporation rate reaches {{convert|3000|mm|abbr=on}}.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} Because of its climate, the area is sometimes counted as one of the ''Furnaces of China'', although the locations included under this heading vary.
{{Turpan weatherbox}}
==Vegetation and agriculture== [[Image:Turpan-calles-d01.jpg|thumb|250px|Qingnian Lu, a [[Turpan]] city street shaded by grapevine [[Trellis (architecture)|trellises]] in China's [[Grape Valley]]]] On the shores of [[Ayding Lake|Aydingkol Lake]], reeds, [[tamarix|tamarisks]], [[Haloxylon|saxauls]], as well as other shrubs and weeds can be found. Away from sources of water, the Turpan Basin is not covered by vegetation. Consequently, agriculture is limited to oasis and depends on a sophisticated irrigation system known as the ''[[Turpan water system|Karez System]]''. The irrigation water comes from the surrounding mountain ranges, in particular from the annual melting of the snow. The Karez System consists of wells, underground channels, ground canals, and small reservoirs, which use the natural slope of the terrain to sustain the water flow and guide the water right to the plants while minimizing evaporation all along the way. The historical record of the system extends back to the [[Han Dynasty]]. The number of Karez systems in the area is slightly below one thousand and the total length of the canals is about {{convert|5000|km|abbr=on}} in length. The Karez System is therefore considered as one of the three great ancient projects in China along with the [[Great Wall of China|Great Wall]] and the [[Grand Canal (China)|Grand Canal]]. Recently, development of groundwater through tubewells has led to a general fall in water tables, and many karez systems have failed. Farming in the Turpan Basin is particularly famous for its fruit. Because of the dry and hot conditions, the fruits grown in the depression have very high concentrations of sugar. They are traditionally processed by drying in open drying barns. The cultivated fruit include: [[Morus (plant)|mulberry]], [[peach]], [[apricot]], [[apple]], [[pomegranate]], [[pear]], [[ficus|fig]], [[walnut]], as well as [[grape]]s, [[watermelon]]s and [[muskmelon]]s. Among the fruit, the grapes stand out: more than 100 varieties of grape are cultivated in the area and it accounts for 90% of China's seedless grape crop. Other specialty agricultural products of the region are [[Donghu Hami melon]]s and [[Gossypium hirsutum|long-staple cotton]].
==Sources== * {{cite journal |last1= Lei |first1= Shao |first2= Karl |last2= Statteggerb |last3= Wenhou |first3= Lic |first4= Bernd J. |last4= Haupt |date= 1999 |title= Depositional style and subsidence history of the Turpan Basin (NW China) |journal= Sedimentary Geology |volume= 128 |issue= 1–2 |pages= 155–169 |doi= 10.1016/S0037-0738(99)00066-4 }} * {{cite journal |last1= Allen |first1= M.B. |last2= Sengör |first2= A.M.C. |last3= Natal'in |first3= B.A. |date= 1995 |title= Junggar, Turpan and Alakol basins as Late Permian to Early Triassic extensional structures in a sinistral shear zone in the Altaid orogenic collage, Central Asia |journal= Journal of the Geological Society |volume= 152 |issue= 2 |pages= 327–338 |doi= 10.1144/gsjgs.152.2.0327 |url= http://jgs.geoscienceworld.org/content/152/2/327 }}

revision.text:
[[File:Woogsee4.jpg|thumb|Baden: the [[Woogsee]] near Rastatt]] [[File:Woog Familienbad.JPG|thumb|Hesse: the [[Großer Woog]] in Darmstadt]] [[File:Eiswoog.jpg|thumb|Rhineland-Palatinate: the [[Eiswoog]] in the [[Palatine Forest]]]] [[File:Möhlwoog1.JPG|thumb|Saarland: the Möhlwoog near Jägersburg]] A '''woog''' (from ''wâc'', a [[Middle High German]] [[hydronym]])<ref name="pwb">{{citation/core|Surname1=[[Pfälzisches Wörterbuch]]|Title=Woog – [http://www.woerterbuchnetz.de/PfWB?lemma=woog ‚größeres stehendes (meist künstlich aufgestautes) Gewässer, Teich, Weiher‘] |Volume=Band 6|At=col.  1456|language=German}}</ref><ref name="dwb">{{citation/core|Surname1=[[Deutsches Wörterbuch]]|Title=Wag – [http://www.woerterbuchnetz.de/DWB?bookref=27,331,21 ‚bewegtes wasser, teich, stauwasser‘] |Volume=Band 27|At=col.  331|language=German}}</ref> is the local name for a body of still water in parts of southwest [[Germany]]. A ''woog'' may be of natural origin or manmade. <!-- == Entstehung == === Natürliche Entstehung === Der Untergrund in südwestdeutschen [[Mittelgebirge]]n besteht oft aus [[Buntsandstein]]. Dieser ist ein guter [[Permeabilität (Geowissenschaften)|Wasserleiter]], der [[Niederschlag|Niederschläge]] filtert. Das Wasser tritt dann über eingelagerte [[Sperrschicht (Hydrologie)|Sperrschichten]] aus [[Tonminerale|Ton]], welche die weitere [[Regenwasserversickerung|Versickerung]] verhindern, in [[Senke (Geomorphologie)|Senken]] wieder hervor. Dadurch haben sich eine Reihe von [[Moor]]en, Moorseen und [[See]]n gebildet.
=== Künstliche Entstehung === In erster Linie als Wasserspeicher für den Betrieb von [[Wasserrad|Mühlen]] oder von [[Klause (Wasserbau)|Klausen]], in denen Holz für die [[Flößerei#Trift|Trift]] gesammelt wurde, wurden durch [[Stausee|Aufstauung]] von Wasserläufen künstliche Wooge angelegt. Diese dienten auch, meist bei [[Kloster|Klöstern]], als [[Aquakultur|Fischzuchtteiche]] oder, aus verbreiterten [[Burggraben|Burggräben]] entstanden, als Teil der [[Befestigung|Stadt- oder Burgbefestigung]], beispielsweise in [[St. Wendel]] und bei der [[Kaiserpfalz (Kaiserslautern)|Kaiserpfalz]] in [[Kaiserslautern]].
Einen vorübergehenden Woog schuf im südpfälzischen [[Wasgau]] der Ritter von [[Burg Berwartstein]], [[Hans von Trotha]], als er nach langjähriger [[Fehde]] mit dem [[Kloster Weißenburg (Elsass)|Kloster Weißenburg]] im Jahre 1485 die [[Lauter (Rhein)|Wieslauter]] bei [[Bobenthal]] zunächst aufstauen und dann den Damm wieder einreißen ließ. So verursachte er in der acht Kilometer unterhalb gelegenen Kleinstadt [[Wissembourg|Weißenburg]] zuerst empfindlichen Wassermangel und dann eine gewaltige Überschwemmung, weshalb der Ritter zunächst mit der [[Reichsacht]] und später auch mit dem [[Kirchenbann]] belegt wurde.
Die [[Sage vom Hecht im Kaiserwoog]] berichtet über eine Begebenheit, die sich 1497 bei der damals von einem künstlichen Gewässer geschützten [[Kaiserpfalz (Kaiserslautern)|Kaiserpfalz von Kaiserslautern]] abgespielt haben soll und angeblich auf ein Ereignis von 1230 zurückgeht. -->
== Distribution of the name == The name is used for waterbodies in the German states of [[Rhineland-Palatinate]] (being especially common in the [[Palatine Forest]]), the [[Saarland]], in [[Regierungsbezirk Darmstadt|South Hesse]] (commonly in the [[Odenwald]]) and in the state of [[Baden-Württemberg]] ([[Regierungsbezirk Nordbaden|Nordbaden]]); even the names of roads or settlements are derived from such bodies of water. Examples are:
=== Baden-Württemberg === * [[Woogsee]], natural lake near [[Rastatt]] in the basin of the [[Kinzig-Murg-Rinne]]
=== Hesse === * [[Großer Woog]], reservoir on the [[Darmbach]]
=== Rhineland-Palatinate === * [[Biedenbacher Woog]], reservoir on the [[Leinbach (Hochspeyerbach)|Leinbach]] * Büttelwoog, campsite near [[Dahn]] * Dämmelswoog, reservoir near [[Fischbach bei Dahn|Fischbach]] * [[Eiswoog]], reservoir on the [[Eisbach (Rhine)|Eisbach]] * Finsterthaler Woog, reservoir on the [[Leinbach (Hochspeyerbach)|Leinbach]] * [[Franzosenwoog]], former reservoir on the [[Hochspeyerbach]] * [[Gelterswoog]], reservoir of tributaries of the Aschbach * [[Hammerwoog]], reservoir in [[Kaiserslautern]] * [[Kammerwoog]], former ''woog'' on the [[Nahe (Rhine)|Nahe]] in Idar-Oberstein, today a section of the river * Katzenwoog, reservoir on the [[Erlenbach (Lauter)|Erlenbach]] near Kaiserslautern * [[Kolbenwoog]], reservoir on a tributary of the Aschbach * Mörstadter Woog, reservoir on the northern perimeter of [[Mörstadt]]<ref name="wormser zeitung">{{cite web |work=[[Wormser Zeitung]] |url=http://www.wormser-zeitung.de/region/vg-monsheim/moerstadt/4835558.htm |title=Idylle am Woog near Musik and Wein |date=2008-07-07 |access-date=2009-09-08 }}</ref> * [[Mühlwoog]], reservoir on the Leinbach, just before its confluence with the [[Hochspeyerbach]] * Niederhausener Woog (also ''Niederhausener reservoir''), reservoir der Nahe between Norheim and [[Niederhausen (Nahe)|Niederhausen]] * Pfälzerwoog (also Pfalzwoog), reservoir on a right tributary of the [[Sauer (Rhine)|Saarbach]] * [[Salzwoog]], district of Lemberg, named after an old reservoir on the [[Salzbach (Lauter)|Salzbach]] * [[Scheidelberger Woog]], nature reserve between [[Bruchmühlbach-Miesau|Miesau]] and [[Hütschenhausen]] * Schweinswoog, reservoir on the [[Eußerbach]] * Seewoog, reservoir on the Leinbach near [[Waldleiningen]] * Sixmeisterwoog reservoir on the Aggenbach near [[Otterberg]] * Spießwoog, reservoir near Fischbach * [[Stüdenwoog]] reservoir on the [[Eppenbrunner Bach]] * [[Vogelwoog]], reservoir and surrounding nature reserve on the edge of Kaiserslautern * Woogfelsen rocks, a [[heritage site]] on the Biedenbacher Woog in [[Frankenstein (Pfalz)]]
=== Saarland === * ''Alter Woog'', road name in the old town of [[St. Wendel]] * ''Am Altwoog'', road name in the [[Neunkirchen (Saar)|Neunkirchen]] district of [[Neunkirchen (Saar)#Furpach|Furpach]] * ''Merwoog'', road name in [[Kirrberg (Homburg)|Kirrberg]] derived from an old reservoir on the [[Lambsbach]] * Möhlwoog, reservoir on the [[Erbach (Blies)|Erbach]] near Homburg-Jägersburg * Woogbachtal (also ''Ensheimer Gelösch''), valley with ponds near [[Saarbrücken Airport|Saarbrücken-Ensheim Airport]] * ''Zum Altwoog'', road name in [[Fürth im Ostertal]]
== References == <references />
